answers.answer: If your tests are "more or less normal," then I would talk with your doctors and ask them exactly what is wrong, especially if you have symptoms (problems).Ask the Neurologist why he put you on the medication Pregab.  Is this medication helping you?Sometimes diabetes or other diseases can cause nerve pain, but there can be other causes for your pain as well.  That is why you need to talk to your doctors who know your history and find out what is wrong.Keep up the exercise, but perhaps back off a little prior to you getting the pain.  Make sure your shoes are comfortable with no seams digging into your feet, and examine your feet daily.  Let us know if you have any other questions.

Well the orthopedic doctor said that since thepain is not localized and keeps moving to different points and is symmetric in nature (both feets), it is related to nerves. Also with x ray, mri and some blood tests like Rheumatoid factor, ESR etc he ruled out conditions like rhemutaoid arthiritis. The neurologist doctor although did not conduct any tests, just looking at the symptoms said it must be musclo skeletal problem and I am worrying too much which may be aggravating the problem. Since I am having problems sleeping he recommended pregab 75. One reason he said it may not be neurological problem is that the problem started after my blood sugar level came down. Vascular surgeon said there may be mild narrowing of the arteries in lower limbs but it is not significant enough to cause this problem so it must be related to nerves. So overall there is no confirmed diagnosis.

Are all these doctors talking with each other regarding your case and sharing the test results?  I encourage you to have them do this so that you get the best care.  You may need to give them permission to do so depending on what country you live in.

These doctors work mostly in different hospitals. I have consulted them based in availability and convenience of reaching where I live. I don't think it is possible to talk to each other and it works that way in my place until u get hospitalized with serious condition when the hospitais  puts a panel of doctors on the case.Anyway I consulted another neurologist today and he said that it can happen if I have been living in high blood sugar condition undiagnosed for long and suddenly brought down the sugar levels. He also conducted nerve conduction test which mentions mild motor neuropathy. He said there is no major damage to nerves but when my blood sugar are controlled and stable the pain should go away. He also prescribed pregab 75 and supplements to be taken for next 3 weeks and come back with status. Hope his diagnosis is correct.

I think you misunderstood me when I mentioned about "are all the doctors talking to each other..."  This is not something you need to do, but they need to do.  You can ask them to send a copy of their report to you other doctors....as simple as that (usually done by fax).  If all your doctors are aware of what is going on, it is in your best interest so that everyone is on the same page and knows what the plan of care is.Give the Pregab some time to work and I'm glad you finally got a diagnosis.  Keep us posted as to how you do :: keeping my fingers crossed for you :: (for good luck).

Thanks a lot for ur best wishes and taking interest in my problem. I will update on how I am doing. Today, a day after the nerve conduction test I dont feel that well. Having restlessness and heaviness on my whole leg, but I am giving it a rest since I have had episodes of restlessness and pain which after a day of rest gone by itself. Hoping things will go well since I have startef taking the prescribed supplement (felicia-od ). Although I am not sure about the vit b12. I was also diagnosed deficient in b12 at the time of diagnosis for diabetes 3 months. The doctor asked me to take lot of injections for that but I took couple of injectiona and then daily doses of b12 for some time. After that in one of the blood tests I get it checked again and thw b12 came above normal range so I stopped taking b12 supplement. I hope b12 supplement do not cause any overdose issues.
Did you notify your doctor that you stopped the B12?  If not, you should let him/her know.  I'm sorry you are not feeling well today.  Try and rest up and I hope you feel better tomorrow.

Yes I did notify him but he prescribed the same medicine (felicia od ) anyway. I think these supplements come in packages and its hard to find a package/ medicine without b12 in it. Even the pregab also is combined with b12.I felt better in the morning today and could go to office, although with some walking and standing I again started getting the warm feeling in the feets and pain in some areas my area near ankles and heels. But this happens usually with me during most working days (from the time this condn started). It goes away with rest during the evening and night and then I am ready for the struggle in next morning.

It is highly likely that the feet pain you are experiencing is to do with nerve damage due to the high sugar levels.I can hear you say, "Yes, but these symptoms started after my sugar levels came down."What happens is well before you become diagnosed as a diabetic, there are changes going on and with that damage to nerves which you will not know that is happening.Vitamin B12 is usually prescribed because lack of this vitamin can cause symptoms of pins and needles.  A blood test would confirm if your Vitamin B12 level is OK or not.  Vitamin 12 is a vitamin that needs to be taken every day and any excess is excreted when you urinate.  If the blood test shows that your Vitamin B12 levels are still low, it is highly likely that your body is not absorbing this through the gut and the doctor would then inject this vitamin about every 3 months.You do not say which medication you started for your diabetes.  Some of these medications do deplete the body of Vitamin B12 and there is no reason for you to stop taking the Vitamin unless the blood tests for this Vitamin show that it is at a good level and on advice from your doctor.It is still very important for you to keep your sugar levels well controlled.  The medication that is usually prescribed in the UK for peripheral nerve damage or damage to nerves in the legs and feet (with symptoms of pins and needles and hotness) is Amitriptyline.  This is an antidepressant and is taken at night.  It is also used for referred pain.  It also helps you to sleep.  Your doctor may prescribe something similar.Make sure that you wear suitable and comfortable walking shoes.  You may find that having insoles in the shoes helpful too.  Now that you are a diabetic, you do need to take care of your feet and yourself.Best wishes.

Thanks for some more useful information. I am taking glimepiride 1mg a day for diabetes. My fasting sugat level is stable now a days at 100 mg/dL as compared to 320 mg/dL when it was diagnosed about 3 montha ago. Post meal about 2 hours after dinner is around 140-150 mg/dL. The b12 tested 3 months ago was 213 pg/ml and then tested again some 1 month back was 1180 pg/ml that is after taking couple of injections and daily oral supplements during that time.The nerve conduction test conducted 2 days ago show the following resultsMOTOR NERVE CONDUCTI9NPeroneal Left Ankle - Head of fibula 37.4 m/sPeroneal Right Ankle -Head of fibula 37.6m/sTibial Left Ankle - Popliteal 40.4 m/sTibial Right Ankle- Popliteal 37.1 m/sSENSORY NERVE CONDUCTIONSural Left 52.7 m/sSural Right 48.3 m/sI dont know if it gives some information about what kind of nerve issue there may be, but may be helpful for a nurologist to comment on my condition

To be honest, I have no idea what the results of your testing means and like you say, your neurologist will explain in detail what these all mean.You have done brilliantly with regard to controlling your sugar levels.I was diagnosed with Type 2 in 2013 and am on Metformin 500SR (slow release).  I did have glucose intolerance for 5 years before being diagnosed and do have peripheral nerve damage with referred pain from spinal problems too.I did experience pain and pins and needles in my feet when I was 39, which happened to be a kidney stone, that baffled my doctors.Hope all goes well for you.Best wishes.

My blood sugar control have to do with many factors apart from mentioned medication.1. I have stopped eating/drinking anything with added sugar.2. I have reduced my carbohydrate intake to the minimum required3. I have increased my intake of vegetables, pulses and fruits and also started including some of milk and yogurt in my regular diet.4. I take a home remedy of a bit of juice of bitter gourd and gooseberry in morning empty stomach every day.5. I eat some of  flaxseeds 2-3 times a day that also helps in many areas other than controlling sugar.6. I have stopped eating potatoes, peas, bananas or anything else which has high glyemic index.7. I take 300mg Alpha Lipoic acid supplemeny almost every day after dinner.What I am not sure is if this change in diet to control my blood sugar is a contributor to my feet pain problem.

question: I was diagnosed with diabetes with high blood sugar levels around 3 months ago. I changed my diet, started medication, and started doing walks as per doctor's advice. My blood sugar levels came to normal with all these changes, which took around 3 weeks. After that  suddenly I got severe pain in my feets. I had to take rest for 2 to 3 days when the pain cooled down and I could walk again. But anytime I walked little faster or little longer the pain would appear again and I had to take rest for couple of days. This went on and off for about 2 weeks and then I thought I should take rest for 2 to 3 weeks. I took rest and the pain cooled down buy still Iwas having pains in different parts of the feet even during rest. This has been now around 2.5 months and I still have mild pain that move around at different places of feet and sometime lower leg. Meantime I have consulted orthopedic doctors, nurologist, rheumatologist and vascular surgeon with basic tests done like x ray, mri, blood tests and ultrasound doppler test. All these tests are more or less normal as per doctors and do not explain the problem.I still continue to suffer from mild pain in my feets and occasionally lower legs, which increases with after doing short walks and cools down in rest but still happen doing rest. After daylong of short walks and standings the pain is more at night and I have to take pain killer and one medicine suggestefd by neurologist (pregab 75) to sleep.What can be the cause of this pain?
title: Pain in feets & lower legs
